acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 2 from its 72h-ErC50 = 1.4 mg/L for algae (Scenedesmus) (AQUIRE, 2010).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. As relevant information, a LD50 value for rats is 100 mg/kg bw (RTECS (2008)) and a LD50 value for rabbits is 59.9 mg/kg bw (RTECS (2008)). The substance is classified into R24 in EU classification (EU-Annex I (2009)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. As relevant information, a LCLo value was 114 mg/L/0.5h (14.25 mg/L/4h) for rats (RTECS (2008)). Since the LCLo value was higher than saturated vapour pressure concentration (0.89 mg/L), the classification criteria for dust was adopted. The substance is classified into R23 in EU classification (EU-Annex I (2009)).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 177 mg/kg bw for rats (EHC No. 216 (2000)), the substance was classified into Category 3. As relevant information, in EU classification, the substance is classified into R25.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 2 since its acute toxicity is Category 2 and there are no adequate data on rapid degradation.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: No data available. Information is available that the substance is corrosive to most metals (IMDG (2006)).

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data from in vivo mutagenicity tests. From in vitro mutagenicity tests, there are reports of a positive Ames test (NTP DB (access on Aug. 2009)) and a negative micronucleus test (EHC 216 (2000)). The substance is an existing chemical substance, for which mutagenicity was established under the provisions of Article 57-3 of the Industrial Safety and Health Law.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure in the molecule

oxidizing_solids.rationale: The substance is an organic compound containing oxygen which is chemically bonded only to carbon or hydrogen.

reproductive_toxicity.rationale: In a rat developmental test by oral administration during the organogenesis period, the mean frequency of soft tissue malformations by defects of principally cardiovascular and craniofacia was significantly increased at the high dose (100 mg/kg bw) at which general toxicity such as reduced bodyweight gain in maternal animals was manifested (Birth Defects (3rd, 2000), HSDB (2009)). However, this report is a "Symposium abstract" (Randall JL et al; Teratology 43 (5): 454 (1991)) and the detailed data are unclear. There is a report that the substance did not affect parameters related to reproductive function when administered to male rats as a single dose or repeated doses for 14 consecutive days (EHC No.216 (2000)), but this test was conducted at one dosage only and the detailed data are not clear. Since no other data are available, classification was not possible due to lack of data.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on reports of "Eye contact causes severe burns" (HSDB (2009)) and corrosive for the skin, the substance was classified into Category 1.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on a report of "Skin contact causes severe burns" (HSDB (2009)) and classification as R35 in EU classification (EU-Annex I (2009)), the substance was classified into Category 1.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: No data available. Although the substance is classified into R43 in EU classification, the evidence is not clear.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: There are reports that inhalation exposures are extremely destructive to the tissue of the mucous membranes and upper respiratory tract (HSDB (2009)) and that inhalation may result in spasm, inflammation and edema of the larynx and bronchi, chemical pneumonitis, and pulmonary edema. Additionally, symptoms of exposure may include burning sensation, coughing, wheezing, laryngitis, shortness of breath (HSDB (2009)). Since these information are reported in a document in List 2, the substance was classified into Category 2 (respiratory system).
